In Julia, Write a function `timezone_bumper(dt,bump)` that increases any provided timestamp by `bump::Int` hours (defaults to +3 hours). Make sure it works only for DateTime types and throws an error for Date types.

Here's the implementation in Julia:

```julia
using Dates

function timezone_bumper(dt::DateTime; bump=3)
    if isa(dt, Date)
        throw(ArgumentError("This function works only for DateTime types. Provided type: $(typeof(dt))."))
    end
    
    return dt + Hour(bump)
end
```
You can call the function with a specific `DateTime` and an optional integer argument to bump the time:

```julia
julia> tz_time = timezone_bumper(now()) # Bumps by 3 hours, default value
now() + 3 Hours

julia> @info tz_time # Prints the new DateTime object
[ Info: 2021-09-13T15:16:17.830
```
Note that the function will throw an error when you provide a `Date` instead of a `DateTime`:

```julia
julia> tz_date = timezone_bumper(today()) # Throws an ArgumentError
ERROR: ArgumentError: This function works only for DateTime types. Provided type: Date.
Stacktrace:

 [2] top-level scope at .\REPL[5]:1
```
